at dealing with this crisis and we have seen terrible seems of migrants being passed from country to country some who have been affected by tear gas being put upon them so i think that this conference and what the eu leaders are doing today is merely playing catch up

with what we should have been doing some time ago and what we need to do now is to implement a plan and to be able to sell at plan to our national parliaments and indeed to our own electorates because we must always remember at the end of the day that we have to tell the people who elect us why we are doing things i declare my interest i am the migrant the united kingdom

so we need to make sure that what we do in our parliaments is explained to our electorates i represent the city of lester sixty of the population of lester originated in india twenty of that figure were expelled as refugees from africa

what we must be very careful of is running ahead of our electorates when we make decisions in places like this we need to be able to enter a period of public diplomacy so people understand what we are doing i welcome the hotspots that have been created but they are long overdue

in respect of the camps in respect of the very good work that they are doing and at the end of the day they are left without the kind of support that they need we need to do more with the north african countries and our committee intends to enter a dialogue with countries like morocco algeria and tunisia unfortunately of course the situation in libya is very well known to us ninety two

of the people who left from north africa and arrived in italy came from libya because after we finished our european campaign in libya we left not one but five different governments and as a result they have added to the migration crisis

we need to make sure that the relocation plan is explained very carefully of course if you divide up one hundred and twenty zero people amongst the twenty eight eu countries then you get four zero two hundred for each country this is simply not going to happen because some countries are just not going to be able to accept them

our prime minister david cameron has committedted taking twenty zero but directly from the camps in syria that brings me to my final two points first is the crucial importance of europol we need to show

our national parliaments that the european union through europol is doing the best possible work in tackling the criminal gangs and i am afraid we have not heard enough about this at this conference they have made billions of euros because of this migration crisis and they will continue to make a huge amount of money i was very her pleased to hear from europol today that there are twenty seven zero suspects

but what my constituents want to see is people being not just arrested but convicted sent to prison and also there asset seazed for trading on the human misery which has resulted in so many people having to risk their lives crossing the mediterranean and so many people dying my final point is the situation in syria is now the subject of much discussion

some countries want to go in and bomb syria my view is we need to be very careful about our foreign policy in these circumstances because unless we are very careful then we will be creating an even greater crisis of migration
so we need to pause and think very carefully about what we are doing in foreign policy because we do not want a repetition of the mistakes we made in iraq and afghanistan and libya

mrs ladies and gentlemen i would now like to give the floor to francesco market telarobia member of the committee of home affairs in the spanish congress iv deputies god afternoonamriden good afternoon honourable members thank you for giving me this opportunity to address you this afternoon obvious speaking in
in spanish now the european union and member states are bound by the charter of fundamental rights the charter sets out the rights that emerge from various constitution and international treaties

that the member states have signed up to in addition eu initiatives on migration and indeed all over eu policies really can be traced back to the charter of fundamental rights recognises some of the following rights human dignity right to life right to fiscal integrity right to freedom security
respect for privacy family life freedom to work and right of asylum protection in the case of expulsion and also non discrimination so those are the fundamental rights that must be guaranteed

those are rights guaranteed through various national constitutions and as i said enshrined at eu level through the charter of fundamental rights that i referred to at the outset but we also have to present the fact that we are seeing play out in central in eastern europe we know that the heads of state and government have met today to run through new measures to ensure a more holistic approach to migration

i believe that todays meeting convened by the libe committee really comes at the right time we are dealing with an emergency a times of emergency rapid short term action is required but we also need to be smart

in the way we manage matters in the long term the spanish government and its ministries have worked hard to enforce reception programmes to deal with asylum seekers and really work with specialised international networks provide support to the individuals in question financing has not been cut

budgets have not been cut indeed the funding was increased in the most recent budget thanks to european funds that were harnessed to this end and can i remind you that spain is a country that was severely hit by the economic crisis in recent years

now the request for international protection has have been quite low quite a lo number of asylum seekers but we have very stable reception centres we have a multidisciplinary approach as well to asylum requests in spain we have a very firm approach and a responsible approach we bear in mind are

reception capabilities and resources we offer a humanitarian approach to those foreigners that come to our territory up until now it has been for economic reasons we have centres run by the ministries we have also leased with ngos and the centres that they run
the spanish government has some figures and as dealt with its commitments unto the juncker plan it is willing to show solidarity when it comes to tackling the humanitarian crisis currently underway
if i may i would like to share with you our experience for decades we have been coping with huge migratory flows we have seen the influx from north africa given the fact that we have territory

on the northern african continent we have seen huge flows in two thousand and six we had mattive influx thirty nine zero hitting the spanish coast we decided to deal with the issue of irregular migration and try to prevent the type of tragegeddes that we saw due to maff years organisations trafficking in human beings we talked about this this morning
the government offices showed themselves to be very effective and as of two thousand and six through to the current day we saw a significant cut in irregular migration on to spanish soil
we worked with countries of origin manage to reduce the risk and save lives so we adopted a smart approach a cooperative approach with frontex for example and other agencies that work in this area

i would mention here close cooperation with neighbouring countries like senegal moritanian morocco thanks to such cooperation the number of migrants arriving on the shores of the canaria island as round ninety ne that is the cut that we have seen
let me be no doubt that migration is the main challenge of our era europe can not become a forttrus

europe must continue to be rooted in the principles of solidarity we should not turn those looking for protection into criminals we need regulation we need to manage our resources and we need to involve all stakeholders all social partners there in put is vital to ensure that the endeavour is successful

in spain we have seen that improving living conditions in countries of origin really is essential we need local effective cooperation with the countries of origin we need to tackle the root causes we need to see genuine improvement in living standards we want to turn migration into an option rather than a vital necessity to survive
solidarity that really is the mainstay for civilised countries but we also need to monitor the european unions external borders that is important

for all member states and all agencies the european union must provide political financial and operative support to those countries with external borders we need to recognise the responsibilities that they take on in all our interests
we also need to work with third countries of transit or origin for irregular migrants for countries of origin we need effective cooperation mechanisms in the short medium and long term
it is vital that we set up a common monitored process or mechanism for dealing with migratory flows we also need to ensure that there are ways to tackle with tackle people smuggler rings
